Executive Summary

Superior Pipeline Company, LLC. (SPC) owns and operates a natural gas liquids recovery facility, the Cashion Gas Processing Plant, in Cashion, Oklahoma. The plant is designed to recover liquid products from natural gas via physical separation, dehydration, refrigeration, and expansion. Petroleum condensates and natural gas liquids are recovered from the inlet pipeline gas.  Section 112(r ) of the Clean Air Act applies to the Cashion plant because it handles and stores process flammables such as methane, ethane, propane, butane, isobutane, pentane and isopentane in excess of threshold quantities. SPC management is aware of potential hazards posed by processing and storing natural gas and natural gas liquids. Programs are established to prevent accidental releases and train personnel for emergency response in the event of a release.  The Cashion plant has no recordable accidents in the past five years.   

SPC has considered the impact of a worst case accident.  In this case, the ¿worst case¿ would be a complete release from the 15,000 gallon NGL storage tank, resulting in instantaneous formation of a vapor cloud which ignites and explodes. Using the EPA¿s RMP*Comp software version 1.07, the potential radius of impact, due to the explosion, was calculated to extend 0.3 miles. Global positioning system (GPS) was utilized to estimate public receptors within a 1 mile radius.  The worst case event would affect two (2) nearby structures, and it was determined that the nearest public receptor is approximately 0.3 miles from the tank.  A consideration of the 0.3 mile radius is incorporated into our notification and emergency response planning.

SPC implements safety programs and procedures designed to prevent and mitigate catastrophic releases. Operation, maintenance, training, and inspection procedures are being implemented. 2.3 Alternative Release Scenario Analyses - §68.28

Gaseous Release from Process Piping:

Instead of assuming release of the entire contents of a vessel containing a flammable gas, SPC decided to consider a more likely scenario such as release from a hole in a vessel or pipe. To estimate the hole size, SPC assumes, for example, the hole size that would result from shearing off a valve or pipe from a process line containing a regulated substance. To estimate the gas leak, the following simplified equation was used to estimate a release rate based on hole size, pipe pressure, and the properties of the gas. This equation applies to choked flow, or maximum gas flow rate. Choked flow generally would be expected for gases under pressure.

QR = HA x Pt x 1/vTt x GF 

To summarize, a pipe containing methane gas is broken.  Methane gas was chosen due to the fact that it has the highest heat of combustion of any element in the process stream.  The release rate was estimated from the above equation. We estimate that the broken pipe would leave a hole with an area (HA) of 6 square inches. The temperature inside the pipe (T, absolute temperature, Kelvin) is 282 K, the air temperature is assumed to be 25 degrees C, and the square root of the temperature T is 16.8. The pressure in the pipe (P) is approximately 750 pounds per square inch absolute (psia). From Exhibit C-2, Appendix C, of EPA 550-B-99-009, the gas factor (GF) for methane is 14. Therefore,

the release rate (QR) is:
3,749 lb/min.  The gas is assumed to leak for a maximum of 10 minutes yielding 37,490 lb methane gas released.  Methane gas was chosen to represent the alternative worst case scenario because it has the highest heat of combustion of any element in the process stream.

3.0 PREVENTION PROGRAM 

3.1 Introduction

The following is a summary of the accident prevention program in place at the Cashion Gas Processing Plant. Processes are regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) risk management program (RMP) regulation and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA's) process safety management (PSM) standard. This summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program.

3.2 Process Safety Information - §68.65:

The Cashion plant keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the process. These documents address chemical processes and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters, specific inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information. The Operations Manager has assigned responsibility for maintaining up-to-date process safety information. 
Chemical-specific information, including toxicity information, permissible exposure limits, physical data, reactivity data, corrosivity data, thermal and chemical stability data is provided in MSDSs (material safety data sheets).  MSDSs are made available to all employees and contract personnel.  When applicable, this information is supplemented by documents that specifically address additional concerns.

Pre Start-Up Review - §68.77   
SPC performs pre-startup safety reviews for new stationary sources and modified stationary sources when the modification is significant enough to require a change in process safety information.  The pre-startup safety review confirms that prior to the introduction of regulated substances to a process:
(1) Construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications;
(2) Safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate;
(3) For new stationary sources, a process hazard analysis has been performed and recommendations have been resolved or implemented before startup; and modified stationary sources meet the requirements contained in management of change, §68.75.
(4) Training of each employee involved in operating a process has been completed.
Compliance Audits - §68.79   
SPC will certify that they have evaluated compliance with the provisions of this subpart at least every three years.  SPC will also verify that procedures and practices developed under this subpart are adequate and are being followed.
The compliance audit will be conducted by at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  A report of the findings of the audit will be developed. The owner or operator will determine and document an appropriate response to each of the findings of the compliance audit, and document that deficiencies have been corrected.  S

PC will retain the two (2) most recent compliance audit reports.



Incident Investigation - §68.81   
SPC health and safety personnel investigate each incident which resulted in, or could have reasonably resulted in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  Incident investigations are initiated as promptly as possible, but not later than 48 hours following the incident.
In the event of such an incident, an investigation team is established.  The team consists of at least one person knowledgeable in the process involved, including a contract employee if the incident involved work of the contractor, and other persons with appropriate knowledge and experience to thoroughly investigate and analyze the incident.
A report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and includes, at a minimum, the following:
(1) Date of incident;
(2) Date investigation began;
(3) A description of the incident;
(4) The factors that contributed to the incident; and,
(5) Any recommendations resulting from the investigation.
SPC has established a system to promptly address and resolve the incident report findings and recommendations. Resolutions and corrective actions are documented.  In addition, the report is reviewed with all affected personnel whose job tasks are relevant to the incident findings.  The review also includes contract employees where applicable.  These incident investigation reports are retained for five years.
Employee Participation - §68.83   
Employee participation is a key element of this program.  SPC has developed a written plan of action regarding the implementation of the employee participation.
